title: Effects of Auditory Brain Stimulation by "Pink Noise" on Memory Capacities in Alzheimer's Disease: Proof of Concept Study
description_brief:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder affecting almost 6% of the world's population over the age of 65. This disease, in its most typical sporadic form, is characterized by an episodic memory impairment linked to a deficit in consolidation. Many studies indicate that sleep promotes this consolidation stage during the deep slow sleep stage by facilitating the transfer of information between the hippocampus and the neocortex.

A method of acoustic brain stimulation at night by pink noises has been recently developed and has shown its effectiveness in strengthening memory consolidation in healthy volunteers. Actually, there is no study observing the effect of this new stimulation method on populations with neurodegenerative pathologies, in particular in AD for which this technique could potentially become a therapeutic option.

The hypothesis is that of a strengthening of the memory consolidation capacities in subjects with AD as has been shown in healthy subjects.

drug: Auditory brain stimulation (phase‑locked "pink noise") — non‑pharmacological intervention
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is nocturnal, phase‑locked acoustic/pink‑noise stimulation intended to enhance slow‑wave sleep and thereby strengthen sleep‑dependent memory consolidation in people with Alzheimer’s disease — i.e., an intervention whose primary aim is to improve cognitive (memory) function rather than to target molecular AD pathology. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Act (key extracted details): The pilot/proof‑of‑concept work uses a wearable headband (e.g., DREEM2 in published pilots) that delivers short bursts of phase‑locked pink noise (reported ~40–50 dB) targeted to the up‑phase of slow oscillations during slow‑wave sleep; studies report a sham condition (no stimulation or marked wave only) as the control. The approach has been piloted in mild–moderate AD and in older adults with memory impairment. citeturn0search3turn0search4turn0search2

Reflect: Given the non‑pharmacological nature (sound stimulation) and the stated goal of strengthening memory consolidation, the trial fits the 'Cognitive enhancer' category (improve cognitive/memory function) rather than 'disease‑targeted biologic' or 'disease‑targeted small molecule' or 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement.' There is no drug to classify. citeturn0search5
